garments.name: Single-Breasted Suit Jacket
garments.description: Classic jacket with one row of buttons and overlapping front panels, the foundation of modern menswear
garments.construction_details: Structured with canvas interlining (full, half, or fused), pad-stitched lapels, functional sleeve buttonholes. Features chest pocket, flap pockets, and internal pockets. Shoulder construction can be natural, roped, or padded depending on style.
garments.key_features: Notch or peak lapels, 1-3 button configuration (2-button most common), center vent or side vents, structured shoulders, working sleeve buttons in bespoke
garments.historical_context: Evolved from military and riding coats in 19th century. Modern single-breasted jacket became standard business attire in 20th century, replacing more formal frock coats.
garments.styling_tips: Two-button jackets most versatile for business. Fasten only top button when standing. Jacket should lightly kiss shoulders when worn. Sleeve should show 1/4-1/2 inch of shirt cuff.

garments.name: Double-Breasted Jacket
garments.description: Formal jacket with two parallel rows of buttons and wide overlap, power dressing staple
garments.construction_details: Similar construction to single-breasted but with wider front overlap requiring additional fabric. Peak lapels most common. Requires precise button balance and placement. Often features ticket pocket.
garments.key_features: 4-6 buttons (usually 6x2 or 4x2 configuration), peak lapels standard, wide front overlap, more formal appearance, military heritage visible in structure
garments.historical_context: Originally military and naval uniform. Became civilian formal wear in 1930s-40s. Revived in 1980s power dressing. Now seen as bold, confident choice.
garments.styling_tips: Keep buttoned when standing (unlike single-breasted). Best worn by taller men due to visual weight. Extremely formal and authoritative appearance. Pairs well with high-waisted trousers.

garments.name: Tuxedo Jacket (Dinner Jacket)
garments.description: Formal evening jacket with satin or grosgrain facings, worn with bow tie for black-tie events
garments.construction_details: Similar to suit jacket but with silk facings on lapels, pocket besom, and buttons. Side adjusters on trousers instead of belt loops. Single-breasted with shawl, peak, or notch lapels (shawl most formal).
garments.key_features: Silk facings, satin or grosgrain, covered buttons, single button closure, no vents (traditional), worn with pleated or piqué front shirt
garments.historical_context: Developed in 1860s as less formal alternative to tailcoat for dinner at home. Named after Tuxedo Park, NY where it became popular in America. Now standard black-tie attire.
garments.styling_tips: Always black or midnight blue. Wear with bow tie (never necktie). Single button, always fastened. Patent leather shoes. White pocket square. Understated elegance is key.

garments.name: Dress Shirt
garments.description: Formal shirt designed to wear with suits or under jackets, featuring structured collar and cuffs
garments.construction_details: Made from cotton or cotton blend, poplin or broadcloth. Features collar with interfacing, button placket, button or French cuffs, shoulder yoke for shape. Longer shirttail for tucking.
garments.key_features: Structured collar, formal button placket, barrel or French cuffs, longer length for tucking, fine fabrics
garments.historical_context: Evolved from undergarment to visible garment. White dress shirt remains most formal option. Collar styles changed with tie fashions through 20th century.
garments.styling_tips: White and light blue most versatile colors. Collar should fit with room for two fingers. Cuffs should extend 1/4-1/2 inch beyond jacket sleeve. Iron for crisp appearance.

garments.name: Oxford Cloth Button-Down (OCBD)
garments.description: Casual shirt with soft button-down collar, American Ivy League staple
garments.construction_details: Made from oxford cloth (basket weave cotton), features buttoned-down collar points, chest pocket (typically), soft unlined collar. Box pleat in back for movement.
garments.key_features: Button-down collar, oxford cloth fabric, soft unstructured collar, chest pocket, casual elegance
garments.historical_context: Collar buttons invented by Brooks Brothers in 1896 after polo players' collars. Became Ivy League uniform. Now smart-casual standard.
garments.styling_tips: Can be worn with or without tie. Works under blazers or alone. White and blue most classic. Slight collar roll is characteristic and desirable.

garments.name: Dress Trousers
garments.description: Formal trousers designed to pair with jackets or blazers, featuring refined cut and details
garments.construction_details: Tailored fit through waist, seat, and leg. Include waistband with hook-and-bar closure, belt loops or side adjusters, front pleats (optional), rear pockets, pressed center creases front and back.
garments.key_features: Can be flat-front or pleated, break determines length, cuffs optional, usually wool or wool blend, pressed creases
garments.historical_context: Separated from suit concept in mid-20th century, allowing business casual mix-and-match. Pleats more traditional, flat-front more modern.
garments.styling_tips: Length should create slight break on shoes for formal wear, no break for modern slim fit. Pleats should lie flat when standing. Cuffs add weight and formality.

garments.name: Chinos
garments.description: Casual cotton twill trousers, bridge between jeans and dress trousers
garments.construction_details: Made from cotton twill, flat-front or single pleat, slanted front pockets, welt or flap back pockets. Lighter construction than dress trousers but more refined than jeans.
garments.key_features: Cotton twill fabric, casual styling, versatile color options (khaki, navy, olive), relaxed but tailored fit
garments.historical_context: Originally military wear (British and US armies in tropical climates). Name from Chinese twill fabric. Became American casual staple in mid-20th century.
garments.styling_tips: Navy and khaki most versatile. Pair with blazers for smart-casual or polo shirts for casual. Can be cuffed or uncuffed. Fit should be clean but not tight.

garments.name: Waistcoat (Vest)
garments.description: Sleeveless garment worn over shirt and under jacket in three-piece suits
garments.construction_details: Tailored to fit close to torso. Back usually silk or satin with adjustable strap for fit. Front matches suit fabric. Usually five or six buttons. No collar (usually), V-neck front.
garments.key_features: Collarless (typically), V-neck front, adjustable back strap, formal or casual depending on style
garments.historical_context: Originally called waistcoat in Britain, vest in US. Part of classic three-piece suit. Became optional as casual dress evolved in 20th century.
garments.styling_tips: Bottom button traditionally left unfastened. Should fully cover waistband when standing. Can be worn without jacket in business casual settings. Adds formality and warmth.

garments.name: Overcoat
garments.description: Long formal coat worn over suits for warmth in cold weather
garments.construction_details: Made from heavy wool, often with lining and possible interlining for warmth. Extends below knee for traditional style, mid-thigh for modern cuts. Set-in sleeves with room for layers. Often features back vent for movement.
garments.key_features: Full length (past knee), formal appearance, structured shoulders, often features back vent for movement, heavy wool construction
garments.historical_context: Essential garment of 19th and early 20th centuries before heated transportation. Remains cold weather formal outerwear standard.
garments.styling_tips: Should have room to comfortably wear suit jacket underneath. Charcoal, navy, and camel most versatile colors. Length depends on height and proportions. Single or double-breasted both acceptable.

garments.name: Trench Coat
garments.description: Water-resistant coat with military origins, featuring distinctive details like epaulettes and belted waist
garments.construction_details: Originally cotton gabardine (Burberry) or ventile cotton. Features double-breasted front, belted waist, shoulder epaulettes, back yoke with rain shield, wrist straps. Modern versions may use synthetic water-resistant fabrics.
garments.key_features: Double-breasted, belted, epaulettes, storm flap, D-rings, raglan or set-in sleeves, knee-length or longer
garments.historical_context: Designed by Burberry and Aquascutum for WWI British officers. Military details remain: epaulettes for rank insignia, D-rings for equipment. Became civilian classic after the war.
garments.styling_tips: Beige/khaki most classic but navy works well. Belt can be tied or buckled. Works over suits or with jeans. Timeless style that works formal or casual.

garments.name: Blazer
garments.description: Structured jacket in solid color or pattern, less formal than suit jacket but more refined than sport coat
garments.construction_details: Similar construction to suit jacket but often unlined or half-lined. Can have metal buttons (nautical style) or standard buttons. Less rigid structure than formal suits.
garments.key_features: Patch pockets common, metal buttons optional, navy most traditional, can wear with non-matching trousers, versatile styling
garments.historical_context: Originated from British naval jackets. Became American preppy staple mid-20th century. Now bridges formal and casual dress.
garments.styling_tips: Navy blazer with gray trousers is classic combination. Can dress up with tie or down without. Versatile for business casual settings. Gold or silver buttons add nautical flair.

garments.name: Sports Jacket
garments.description: Casual jacket in textured or patterned fabric, most relaxed tailored jacket option
garments.construction_details: Softer construction than suit jackets, often unlined or partially lined. Made from textured fabrics like tweed, corduroy, or linen. Patch pockets common. More relaxed fit.
garments.key_features: Textured or patterned fabrics, patch pockets, casual styling, softer construction, country or weekend wear associations
garments.historical_context: Originally for country sports and weekend wear, distinct from town business suits. Tweed jackets particularly associated with British country life.
garments.styling_tips: Pairs with jeans or chinos for weekend wear. Tweed for fall/winter, linen or cotton for spring/summer. Can have elbow patches for extra country character. Most casual tailored option.

garments.name: Polo Shirt
garments.description: Knitted cotton shirt with collar and placket, combining comfort with smart appearance
garments.construction_details: Knitted from cotton piqué or jersey. Features ribbed collar and sleeve cuffs, 2-3 button placket. Side vents for comfort. Can have chest pocket.
garments.key_features: Knit construction, collar, button placket, comfortable, casual but refined
garments.historical_context: Invented by René Lacoste in 1926 for tennis. Replaced woven tennis shirts. Became preppy American staple and smart-casual standard worldwide.
garments.styling_tips: Tucked or untucked depending on formality. Works under blazers or alone. Solid colors most versatile. Fit should be trim but not tight. Collar should maintain shape.
